title: Liquid Cell Electron Microscopy with Self-Supervised Machine-Learning Denoising Framework
content: Liquid cell electron microscopy (EM) gains attention as one of the main analytical methods in materials science because it allows real-time observations of materials in their native phase at sub-nanometer scale resolution. Molecular or atomistic mechanistic understanding of nucleation, growth, and structural transformations of materials have not achieved enough at the nanoscale or below [1, 2]. It is mainly because of a lack of appropriate analytical methods that can obtain in-situ structural information with a spatial resolution at such small length scale along with sub-msec temporal resolution. The liquid cell EM offers an opportunity to directly observe diverse classes of chemical reactions of materials nucleation, crystallization, to diverse types of phase transformations.
